Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Constriction of Cell Membranes by Helix-Shaped Rods
Award.AbstractNarration:
When material needs to be transported around the cell, the cell membrane forms a bud surrounding the material. This is a step in nearly all biological processes. The protein dynamin is responsible for detaching these buds from the body of the membrane by forming a helix-like shape around the neck of the bud, constricting it. The details of how dynamin does this, though, are somewhat mysterious. Does dynamin use fuel from its environment to tighten around the neck of the bud? How small can dynamin constrict the radius of the neck? These questions cannot be answered without understanding how the membrane responds to constriction forces from a helix-shaped rod. This project will focus on developing mathematical models to investigate this process. This work will be performed at the Beijing Normal University in collaboration with Professor Zhanchun Tu, renowned for his theory of membrane elasticity using differential forms.

Many models have been proposed likening dynamin's function to that of a garrote, ratchet, or spring. In this project Guven's auxiliary variables approach will be used to put past models on a firmer mechanical footing. A thermodynamic model of dynamin as a molecular motor will also be investigated, with special regard to such a motor's maximum power and efficiency. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Ministry of Science and Technology of China.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of my EAPSI funding, I was able to travel to China and establish an ongoing collaboration between researchers in Beijing and the United States. This collaboration represents a friendly and positive element in the most important bilateral relationship in the world today. As conflict between our countries grows in other areas, scientific collaboration unites us. 

The work I accomplished while in China helps us understand how cells and organelles divide. A protein called dynamin drives this division by forming stiff filaments around the narrow waists connecting the two compartments. As dynamin winds around this connection, it forms a helix. The helix somehow constricts the waist until it is so thin that it spontaneously breaks, separating the two compartments. This division is an essential function, and is relatively unchanged in many biological contexts: it is how different parts of the cell communicate and how new cells are formed in everything from fungi to fruit flies to humans. It is especially important in communication between neurons, where a mutation in the gene that encodes dynamin can cause disease.

Our research is developing a theoretical model of this process. It is not clear why the waist splits, or at what point. Biologists have proposed many models of how dynamin works, but have been unable to agree on what its exact role is. We aim to address this question by finding detailed implications of each model. In this study, we consider the dynamin-waist system as a rigid helix on a thin surface that resists bending. Hopefully, our model will illustrate what exactly such helical filaments are capable of. 

So far, this research has established a few interesting findings, though our results are not final. We have shown that in certain limiting cases, the pitch of the helix (that is the separation between adjacent rungs) plays a crucial role in making the waist unstable. For approximately cylindrical waists, increasing the pitch of the helix causes the waist to narrow dramatically. If the waist becomes narrower than the thickness of the surface, it will become unstable. On the other hand, for waists subject to high tension, there is a critical pitch at which the waist collapses. These findings show that our model holds promise, and has a good chance of accurately explaining dynamin-mediated fission.
